newsitem.title: BRAZIL: CVRD sale reshapes Brazil steel sector - Flemings.
newsitem.headline: CVRD sale reshapes Brazil steel sector - Flemings.

text.p: Last week's privatization of iron ore company Cia Vale do Rio Doce has helped reshape the Brazilian steel sector, Robert Fleming & Co said.
"This year is turning out to be a revolution in the sector and CVRD's privatization is one key catalyst," Fleming analyst Raphael Biderman said in a report.

The government's sale of a controlling stake in CVRD will give its new owner, a group led by steelmaker Cia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN), greater leverage in setting world iron prices and near control of the local steel industry, he said.
The Valepar consortium paid 3.34 billion reais ($3.15 billion) for a 41.7 percent voting stake in CVRD.
The privatization is likely to shake up Brazil's steel sector because CVRD owns stakes in steel makers Cia Siderurgica de Tubarao (CST), Usiminas, Acominas and Siderar, Biderman said.

The sale will prompt a short-term rise in CSN's financial costs, as it will have to raise its indebtedness by 1.3 billion reais ($1.23 billion). But the firm should benefit over the long term from "extraordinary strategic forces," he added.

"We believe that CVRD's new shareholders will push CSN to be more aggressive in price negotiations with global iron ore consumers in order to weaken the negotiating power of the Asian steel producers," Biderman said.
Today, Asian steelmakers frequently play Australian iron miners against CVRD through skillful timing, he added.
But CSN and its pension fund partners in the group that now controls CVRD can now "put upward price pressure on their steel competitors in Asia and Europe for iron ore sourcing," Biderman said.
While CVRD operates the world's largest iron mine Carajas, CSN's demand for iron is met by its own mines. But the sale gives CSN an indirect stake in a main local competitor, Usiminas.
